awd_titl_txt: AitF: Collaborative Research: Algorithms and Mechanisms for the Distribution Grid
awd_abstract_narration:
The electricity distribution grid?the low-voltage line networks that distribute power to end consumers?is about to undergo a major transformation. More and more consumers are becoming ?prosumers,? namely consumers and producers of power at the same time, by installing solar panels (PVs) on their home roofs and by purchasing electric vehicles, which may be used for energy storage. Traditionally, power in distribution grids has flown one way: from the substation to the end consumer. In the new world of prosumers, distribution grids need to accommodate flow in both directions. This is challenging the existing wire and transformer abilities to serve load at acceptable quality levels. Moreover, the increasing number of prosumers is resulting in dramatically higher uncertainty in demand forecasting, which, with further prosumer increase, may prove unsustainable and ultimately threaten the utility companies? operation and business viability. The research from this award will advance the fields of computation and economics as well as the power systems domain, by contributing with novel algorithmic and mechanism design problem formulations and techniques, and with solutions that can enable improved distribution grid planning and operation. In terms of broader impact, this research has the potential to improve aspects of the grid such as planning for increased integration of renewable energy resources, mitigation of risks associated with variability of renewables, better management of congestion in the face of strategic prosumers and ultimately provide for more reliable, cost effective and efficient operation of the grid. 

The goal of this project is to help the distribution grid and its participants transition from its current functionality of serving mostly traditional consumers, to the future grid that needs to sustainably integrate prosumers, renewables and distributed energy resources, via: (1) Developing simplified mathematical models to solve combinatorial and incentive problems that will enable the future power grid to sustain massive growth in renewables and distributed energy resources; (2) Designing new algorithmic and mechanism design approaches that reduce congestion, and improve the investment and operational efficiency of the grid while further enhancing its reliability; (3) Working with Distribution Utilities for real-world models and operational advice, while facilitating the transfer of research findings to practice.  The scope of the project includes (i) distribution network reconfiguration, (ii) distribution system upgrades and (iii) market mechanisms for supply-demand balancing.  The research will use methods from approximation algorithms and mechanism design, such as submodular optimization, stochastic combinatorial optimization, and price of anarchy analysis.

por.por_cntn:
Algorithms in the Field: Collaborative Research, Algorithms and Mechanisms for the Distribution Grid

Michael Caramanis, Principal Investigator, Boston University

 

The project has focused on developing algorithms that can solve practical problems standing on the way of enabling electric power systems to provide clean energy efficiently and reliably.

In collaboration with our University of Texas Austin colleagues led by Professor Nikolova and several electric utility companies, we have developed algorithmic and software tools that:

-Can coordinate millions of flexible distributed consumption and generation resources such as Electric Vehicle and roof top Photovoltaic Generation installations so that they can be incorporated to the grid with minimal infrastructure investment. In particular, our tools have been shown on real grids to be able to increase by fivefold the hosting capacity of Electric Vehicles on existing distribution networks.

-Can mitigate transmission line congestion and thus maximize the amount of wind generation that can be transported from wind farms to load centers.

-Can develop hourly day-ahead-market electricity prices that reflect non-smooth (in technical vocabulary non-convex) incremental costs over space and time, and, use them to encourage market participants to abide by socially optimal operating schedules. Whereas with today’s Locational Marginal cost Prices (LMPs), 30-50% of generating units self-schedule, our pricing tool is capable of reducing self-scheduling instances substantially and save billions of dollars annually.

We have (i) proven the value proposition of saving the electric power industry billions of dollars per year (ii) have disseminated our results broadly to the community of research scholars and practitioners through professional publications, conference presentations, individual utility lectures, and focused workshops, and finally, (iii) our algorithmic tools have been designed so that they are compatible with those used in current practice and can be potentially incorporated into today’s software management systems with reasonably straight forward extensions. We are thus reasonably confident that they will be acceptable to stakeholders and that they will be adopted and commercialized by the electric power industry.

Modified by: Michael C Caramanis
